facts.text: Lands situated in villages of Telaiya and Debipur were notified under ss. 14 and 21 of the Bihar Private Forest Act, 1947 on June 11, 1948.
Lands were again notified under s. 29 of the Indian Forest Act in 1953 and 1954.
Lands notified for acquisition under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 in 1959 under Acquisition Cases Nos. 3 and 4 of 1959-60 before the Additional Land Acquisition Officer, Hazaribagh.
Government took action under s. 17(4) of the Land Acquisition Act dispensing with proceedings under s. 5A.
Notifications under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act issued simultaneously.
Proceedings under ss. 9 and 11 of the Land Acquisition Act taken.
Government withdrew from acquisition some lands earlier notified under ss. 4 and 6 while proceedings pending before Land Acquisition Officer.
Land Acquisition Officer excluded compensation in respect of withdrawn lands from computation.

Appellant filed writ petitions in Patna High Court under Art. 226 seeking directions to Land Acquisition Officer to award compensation for withdrawn lands; petitions rejected by judgment dated October 14, 1966.
After tentative valuation, Government decided not worthwhile to acquire entire area notified and withdrew substantial portion.
Appellant alleged Forest Department unlawfully took possession after s. 29 Indian Forest Act notification and continued in possession.
Government denied taking possession in 1954 or under s. 17(1) Land Acquisition Act.
High Court not satisfied from evidence that Government took possession in 1954; treated as disputed question of fact.
Divisional Forest Officer, Kodarma Division wrote letter on October 1, 1958 stating forests in possession of Forest Department since sometime past.
Requisition by Divisional Forest Officer to Land Acquisition Officer on January 24, 1959 stating land demarcated and possession taken under s. 29(3) Indian Forest Act, already under possession.
Divisional Forest Officer filed affidavit explaining statements under erroneous impression about effect of s. 29 notification.
Letter from Divisional Forest Officer to Land Acquisition Officer on August 11, 1959 mentioning dates of possession as 8th December 1953 and 22nd November 1954 based on notification dates.
Entry in order-sheet of Land Acquisition Officer on October 17, 1959: Shri B. J. Yadav Kgo to deliver possession at spot to representative of R.O. on 16-11-59; draft addressed to R.O. signed.
Respondent stated order for possession on 16-11-59 not implemented.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the Government of Bihar was competent to withdraw from acquisition certain lands sought to be acquired under Acquisition Cases Nos. 3 and 4 of 1959-60 before the Additional Land Acquisition Officer, Hazaribagh.

petitioner_arguments.text: After lands notified under s. 29 Indian Forest Act, Forest Department unlawfully took possession and continued in possession; thus after s. 6 notifications, Government became owner and incompetent to withdraw.
Alternatively, Government became full owner when Collector caused public notice under s. 9(1) Land Acquisition Act.
Lands actually taken possession of by Collector under s. 17(1) Land Acquisition Act, hence vested in Government.
Once possession taken in 1953/1954, unnecessary to prove possession under s. 17(1); vesting on expiry of 15 days after s. 9(1) notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Lt. Governor of Himachal Pradesh v. Avinash Sharma

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'whenever the appropriate government so directs' in s. 17(1) refers to urgency, not taking possession; urgency established by s. 17(4) notification, vesting after 15 days from s. 9(1) notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 17(1), s. 17(4), s. 9(1) Land Acquisition Act

respondent_arguments.text: Denied Government took possession in 1954 or under s. 17(1); denied ownership on s. 6 or s. 9(1) notices.
Order for possession on 16-11-59 not implemented.
Divisional Forest Officer statements based on erroneous impression.

court_reasoning.text: No satisfactory evidence that Government took possession in 1953/1954; disputed fact, High Court justified in not pronouncing under Art. 226; appellant can seek other remedy if unlawful possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Irrelevant for decision whether Government unlawfully took possession in 1954.

court_reasoning.text: Government becomes owner only when Collector takes possession under s. 16 or s. 17(1); until then, no vesting. Withdrawal under s. 48(1) possible if possession not taken under those sections.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Possession in s. 48 refers to possession under s. 16 or s. 17(1).

court_reasoning.text: No material showing Government directed Collector under s. 17(1) or possession taken thereunder; s. 17(1) requires Government direction in urgency, after 15 days from s. 9(1) notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence of direction or possession under s. 17(1).

court_reasoning.text: Lt. Governor case distinguished: there, prior possession plus s. 17(1)/(4) and s. 9(1) proceedings; here, no s. 17(1) action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No support for automatic vesting after s. 9(1) without s. 17(1).

court_reasoning.text: s. 17(1) plain: 'whenever appropriate government so directs' refers to taking possession, not declaration of urgency; even in urgency, Government may not direct immediate possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot construe s. 17(1) to vest lands automatically after s. 17(4).

holdings.text: Government competent to withdraw from acquisition under s. 48(1) Land Acquisition Act as possession not taken under s. 16 or s. 17(1).

precedents_cited.case_name: Lt. Governor of Himachal Pradesh v. Avinash Sharma
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as there prior possession plus s. 17(1)/(4) and s. 9(1) proceedings deemed possession under s. 17(1); not applicable here without s. 17(1) action.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs acquisition proceedings, withdrawal competent under s. 48(1) if no possession under s. 16/17(1); vesting only on such possession.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Forest Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Notification under s. 29 does not confer possession or ownership justifying withdrawal bar.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Private Forest Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior notifications do not enable possession.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court declined to decide disputed facts in writ jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed as Government competent to withdraw lands under s. 48(1) Land Acquisition Act since no possession taken under s. 16 or 17(1); parties to bear own costs. Assurance recorded that Bihar Government will not realise interest on loans advanced for development from dates of s. 29 notifications.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs

key_quotes.text: "Except in the case provided for in section 36, the Government shall be at liberty to withdraw from the acquisition of any land of which possession has not been taken."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s. 48(1) Land Acquisition Act central to holding on withdrawal competence.

key_quotes.text: "The Government becomes the owner of the lands notified for acquisition only when the Collector takes possession of those lands either under s. 16 or under s. 17(1)."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In our judgment s. 17(1) is plain and unambiguous. The expression 'whenever the appropriate government so directs' in that section refers to the taking of possession and not to the declaration of urgency."
key_quotes.speaker: court
